Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Sea-level Rise and Vegetation Controls on Deltaic Landform Evolution: A Coupled Experimental and Numerical Modeling Study
Award.AbstractNarration:
Deltas are home for 25% of the human population (Syvitski et al., 2005). Across the world, combinations of changes in sea-level-rise rates, land use changes in the watersheds the feed deltas, and human activities on deltas themselves are causing rapid changes to delta landscapes and loss of valuable habitats and ecosystem services. Science for predicting changes in delta landscapes, ecosystems, and coastlines is now urgently required to successfully evaluate and implement plans to improve sustainability for deltas globally. However, changes on deltas are controlled by an array of interactions between coastal rivers, plants and animals, hurricanes and storms, and a range of human manipulations. The proposed study will enhance our understanding of, and ability to predict how deltas will respond to changes in climate and land-use forcing, focusing on both physical and biological aspects of delta systems using laboratory flume and computational experiments.

Physical delta experiments will be conducted in the University of Texas (UT) Sediment Transport and Earth-surface Processes (STEP) basin, which allows for independent and precise controls of the major geological factors: sediment supply and relative sea level rise (RSLR). These experiments will also be the first to investigate interactions between physical and biological processes in shaping deltas. Experiments will involve seeding the delta surface with small plants (Alfalfa) at different spatial densities. The ecosystem is simplified in the experiments but still naturally coevolving with a growing and self-organizing fluviodeltaic system. Computational modeling efforts, based on the results of the physical experiments, will produce a reduced complexity model that captures the main eco-morphodynamic feedbacks under rapid relative sea-level rise over engineering and geological time scales. The resulting computational models will provide a platform for experiments addressing the ecomorphodynamic evolution of a range of delta types, under disparate sets of forcing (e.g. river vs. wave dominated) and under various scenarios of land-use and climate changes. The scientific insights to be gained through the coupled laboratory experiments and computational modeling include: 1) the fluviodeltaic system's response to RSLR, in particular, changes in avulsion (flood) frequency and shoreline roughness, 2) the self-organization of the deltaic distributary channel network that coevolves with vegetation, 3) the effects of spatial variation in vegetation density on channel avulsion location and frequency, and 4) how the feedbacks from vegetation dynamics during rapid RSLR affect deltaic landforms and resulting stratigraphy. This work will produce the first quantitative eco-morphodynamic model based on controlled laboratory experiments, allowing exploration of future changes in fluviodeltaic landscapes, channel activity, and vulnerability for a range of delta types and RSLR rates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Deltas across the globe provide livelihoods sustaining more than 25% of the human population. Science for predicting delta/coastline evolution is now urgently required to successfully evaluate and implement master plans for deltas around the world to restore and secure coastal sustainability. Given the array of interactions between river, coastal, and wetland processes—and the facts that deltaic processes involve both physical and biological components, as well as human manipulation of the terrestrial watershed and delta environments—our understanding of and ability to predict delta evolution remains limited.

Since Hurricane Katrina (August 29, 2005), plans to better manage the Mississippi River Delta have gain greater prominence. Deltaic coastline evolution influences fresh-water supply to wetland habitat, management for salt-water intrusion, and storm surge protection for New Orleans and adjacent cities. Understanding the processes and controls on delta growth will increase the chances for success of the plans to restore and manage the Mississippi River Delta.

This project addressed how deltas develop—what processes determine the characteristics of the landscape and ecosystems, and how they tend to change through time—and how those processes depend on land-use changes and rates of sea-level rise. This project focused on an aspect of deltas that has been difficult to study: the interactions between vegetation growth and the patterns of river flow and sediment movement. Vegetation affects the flow of water and transport of sediment, but the reverse is just as true. Using a combination of experimental delta models in a laboratory flume and complementary computer models, this project has helped illuminate how interactions between developing vegetation and delta growth can lead to very different types of deltas. When vegetation can develop rapidly enough to stabilize channels, a delta like the Mississippi with one slowly changing channels and a very crenulated coastline, evolves. When channels tend to shift too rapidly to allow vegetation to become well established, deltas have smoother shorelines, and the flow and sediment shift from one location to another more rapidly. These different types of deltas (and possibilities that are in between these extremes) tend to retain different amounts of the sediment that the river delivers, and distribute the fresh water in different ways. Better understanding what processes lead to different types of deltas, resulting from this project, will enable decision makers and planners to better forecast and manage future landscape changes in coastal Louisiana in response to the current global environmental changes, e.g., the accelerated sea-level rise and reduction in the sediment transport to the river delta.

The findings of this project extend well beyond the context of the Mississippi Delta, however. The Mississippi is relatively little affected by waves. However, many large deltas worldwide are more strongly influenced by wave-driven transport of sediment away from the river mouth and along the shore. In addition, the Mississippi river has been held in place for several decades by engineering structures, but on other deltas rivers episodically ‘avulse’ or change their course. Such avulsions lead to the previously active part of the delta being abandoned, while a new ‘lobe’ starts growing—with obvious ramifications for human infrastructure (such as cities and ports). One of the computer (numerical) models developed in this project addresses how coastal processes—transport of sediment along the shore, and coastal erosion related to sea-level rise—interact with river processes, including avulsions. Experiments with this new model suggest that some of the previous assumptions about what determines where and how often avulsions occur, and whether they occur more often as sea-level-rise rates increase, might not apply widely to natural deltas.   

In addition to the findings resulting from the laboratory and numerical-model experiments conducted during this project, the numerical models produced as part of this project will be widely available through the Community Surface Dynamics Modeling System. The availability of these models will allow researchers worldwide to assess the long-term consequences of human decision about land use and manipulations of delta processes (wetland and river processes)—consequences that likely range from drastically altering the size and shape of major deltas, to increasing flood risks potentially for hundreds of kilometers upstream. Such forecasting ability will help inform decision makers and planners—helping them to avoid unwelcome surprises and to make decisions that will steer the evolution of deltas and the human developments on them into desired outcomes.
